title: Sunset Sanity: How to End Your Day Without Spiraling Into Stress
subtitle: A No-Nonsense Guide for Adults with Autism, ADHD, or Both
author: Rhys Morgan
content_html:
Let’s be real: the end of the day can feel like a minefield. For adults with autism, ADHD, or the chaotic combo of both, winding down often turns into a stress spiral instead. Your brain’s buzzing, the to-do list is mocking you, and somehow, you’re replaying that awkward thing you said at lunch. Sound familiar? This isn’t about fluffy self-care platitudes—bubble baths won’t fix this. It’s about practical, no-BS strategies to shut down the day without losing your mind.

Here’s how to take control, tailored to the way your neurodivergent brain works.

Why Evenings Suck for Us

Autism, ADHD, or both—it doesn’t matter. Our brains don’t come with an off switch. Autistic folks might get stuck in rigid routines or overwhelmed by sensory leftovers from the day. ADHDers might hyperfocus on unfinished tasks or bounce between a million thoughts. Combined? It’s a perfect storm of overstimulation and distraction. Left unchecked, this spirals into stress that wrecks your sleep and tomorrow’s vibe.

The goal: end the day feeling human, not like a frayed live wire. Let’s break it down.

Step 1: Dump the Day

Your brain’s a hoarder—it holds onto everything. Get it out.

Brain Dump: Grab a notebook or your phone. Write every thought, task, or worry rattling around. No filter, no judgment—just purge. “Forgot to email Steve” or “Why did I eat that third taco?” It all goes down. Takes 5 minutes, saves hours of mental looping.

Autism Hack: If you thrive on structure, use a template—categories like “Work,” “Home,” “Random.”

ADHD Hack: Set a timer for 3 minutes. Race it. Done is better than perfect.

This isn’t journaling. It’s a mental trash can. Once it’s on paper, it’s not your problem tonight.

Step 2: Signal the Shutdown

Transitions are brutal when your brain doesn’t shift gears naturally. Create a clear “day’s over” cue.

Pick a Ritual: Something simple. Turn off your work laptop and say “done” out loud. Light a specific candle. Play the same chill song. Consistency trains your brain to switch modes.

- Autism Tip: Lean into sensory predictability—same smell, sound, or motion every night.

ADHD Tip: Make it dopamine-friendly. Pair it with a snack or a quick scroll (5 minutes max—set a timer).

No cue? Your brain keeps running like a hamster on a wheel. Give it a finish line.

Step 3: Tame the Overload

Evenings amplify overstimulation. Too much noise, light, or unfinished crap piles up fast.

Sensory Check: Dim lights, ditch screens, or grab noise-canceling headphones. If you’re autistic, you know what sets you off—cut it now. ADHD? Clutter’s your enemy—shove it out of sight.

- One-Task Rule: Pick one low-stakes thing to wrap up. Fold laundry, not “plan my life.” Small wins calm the chaos.

- Combined Chaos: Overwhelmed and distracted? Sit still for 60 seconds. Breathe. Reset.

You’re not fixing everything tonight. You’re just surviving till morning.

Step 4: Sidestep the Rabbit Holes

ADHDers chase late-night hyperfocus. Autistic minds replay the day’s glitches. Both? You’re doomed without guardrails.

- Set a Cutoff: Decide when “thinking time” ends—say, 9 PM. After that, no problem-solving, no ruminating.

- Distraction Bait: Keep a go-to wind-down handy. Podcast, puzzle, or doodling—something engaging but not intense.

- Reality Check: Tell yourself, “This can wait.” Write it down if you must, then let it go.

Your brain’s a liar at night. Don’t trust it past curfew.

Step 5: Land the Plane

Sleep’s the goal, but it’s not instant. Ease into it.

- Wind-Down Buffer: Give yourself 30-60 minutes of low-key time. No screens, no stress. Read, stretch, stare at the wall—whatever works.

- Autism Focus: Same routine, same order. Predictability is your friend.

- ADHD Focus: Keep it novel but calm—rotate audiobooks or fidget toys.

Crash landing into bed after a spiral? Recipe for disaster. Glide in instead.

The Payoff

Do this right, and you’re not just surviving the night—you’re setting up a better tomorrow. Less stress means better sleep, sharper focus, and fewer meltdowns. It’s not magic; it’s strategy.

But it’s on you to tweak it. What works for your autistic side might bore your ADHD half to death. Experiment. Fail. Adjust. Just don’t quit.
